section.title: Countable and uncountable nouns
section.sectiontitle: Countable nouns have a singular and plural form.
section.text2a: There are a lot of skyscrapers in the city centre.
section.sectiontitle2: Uncountable nouns do not have a plural form. You can use them with is/was but not are/were.
section.text3a: Traffic is bad in the city centre.

section.title: Quantifiers some, any, no
section.sectiontitle: We use some with countable and uncountable nouns when we don't know exactly how many/much. We sometimes use it in questions where we think the answer will be yes.
section.text2a: Can I have some strawberries, please? Yes, of course.
section.sectiontitle2: We use not any or no with countable or uncountable nouns in the negative. We use any in questions where the answer could be yes or no.
section.text3: There are no Italian restaurants near here.
section.text3a: There aren't any Italian restaurants near here.
section.text4a: Are there any shops near here? No, there aren't .

section.title: Other quantifiers
section.sectiontitle: We use a few with countable nouns for a small number of and a lot with countable or uncountable nouns for a large number of.
section.text1a: I've got a few things I'd like to discuss with you.
section.text2a: There are a lot of nice places to eat near here.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative and question, we use much for uncountable nouns and many for countable nouns.
section.text4a: Are there many tourists at this time of year?

section.title: Other quantifiers
section.sectiontitle: We use too much/too many with a negative meaning. We use them to mean more than the right amount.
section.text1a: I can't work here. There's <b>too much noise.
section.text2a: There are too many people in this classroom.
section.sectiontitle2: Not enough also has a negative meaning. We use it to mean less than the right amount.
section.text3a: There isn't enough rice for everyone.
